A hyperbox of dimensioii N contains N 2 line segments. It. is a subset of a wire frame model of an N-dimensional box (with N * ZN-' segments):
The hyperbox appears less cluttered.

A hyperhox of dimension N has N ( N -1)/2 parallelograms called faces. A fundamental property of the hyperbox is that for each pair of canonical segments, there is exactly one face with edges parallel to the two segments. Thus, the hyperbox is particularly convenient for identifying or displaying information associated with the 2-dimensional subspaces of N-dimensional space.

For each canonical segment, there are N -1 other segments with the same length and orientation. These N segments form a direction set of the hyperbox. A hyperbox of dimension N -1 can be obtained by collapsing all the segments of a direction set to have zero length:

Selecting a point on a segment implicitly se1ect.s the corresponding points on the other segments of the same direction set. These points may he connected by a sequence of line segments parallel to existing segments. Such a sequence will be called a cut. It is often fruitful t o cut a direction set IC times: then split, it into k + 1 hyperboxes of dimension N :

then collapse each of these hyperhoxes along the cut. Loosely speaking, a tensor is a matrix with an arbitrary number of dimensions. The hyperbox was developed to depict tensors within the ALEX visual programming paradigm. Each of the direction sets of a hyperbox corresponds to a dimension of a tensor. Operations 011 tensors can be defined in terms of their effect on a typical sltce, where a slice is a tensor with one fewer dimension obtained by fixing one coordinate of the original tensor. (Thus, the slices of a matrix are its rows and columns, and the slices of a vector are its elements.) A slice can be represented as a c u t through the tensor's hyperbox. A slice can he selected by clicking on an edge; operations on pairs of dimensions (such as a partial transpose) can be indicated hy clicking in a parallelogram.
